first-declension.title: First Declension Nouns
first-declension.description: Master the first declension noun endings and common vocabulary

cards.question: What is the nominative singular ending for first declension nouns?
What is the genitive singular ending for first declension nouns?
What is the dative singular ending for first declension nouns?
What is the accusative singular ending for first declension nouns?
What is the ablative singular ending for first declension nouns?
What is the nominative plural ending for first declension nouns?
What is the genitive plural ending for first declension nouns?
What is the dative plural ending for first declension nouns?
What is the accusative plural ending for first declension nouns?
What is the ablative plural ending for first declension nouns?
What is the Latin word for 'girl'?
What is the Latin word for 'woman'?
What is the Latin word for 'earth' or 'land'?
What is the Latin word for 'water'?
What is the Latin word for 'hour'?
What case is 'puellārum' and what does it mean?
What case is 'terrīs' and what does it mean?
cards.answer: Dative or Ablative plural - 'to/for the lands' or 'by/with/from the lands'

second-declension.title: Second Declension Nouns
second-declension.description: Learn second declension masculine and neuter noun patterns

cards.question: What is the nominative singular ending for second declension masculine nouns?
What is the genitive singular ending for second declension nouns?
What is the dative singular ending for second declension nouns?
What is the accusative singular ending for second declension masculine nouns?
What is the ablative singular ending for second declension nouns?
What is the nominative plural ending for second declension masculine nouns?
What is the genitive plural ending for second declension nouns?
What is the accusative plural ending for second declension masculine nouns?
What is the nominative singular ending for second declension neuter nouns?
What is the accusative singular ending for second declension neuter nouns?
What is the nominative plural ending for second declension neuter nouns?
What is the key rule for neuter nouns in Latin?
cards.answer: The nominative and accusative forms are always the same in both singular and plural

cards.question: What is the Latin word for 'friend' (masculine)?
What is the Latin word for 'war'?
What case is 'amīcōrum' and what does it mean?

verbs-present.title: Present Tense Verbs
verbs-present.description: Master present tense conjugations for all four conjugations

cards.question: What is the first person singular present tense ending?
What is the second person singular present tense ending?
What is the third person singular present tense ending?
What is the first person plural present tense ending?
What is the second person plural present tense ending?
What is the third person plural present tense ending?
What is the stem vowel for first conjugation verbs?
What is the stem vowel for second conjugation verbs?
What is the stem vowel for third conjugation verbs?
What is the stem vowel for fourth conjugation verbs?
What is the Latin infinitive for 'to love'?
What is the Latin infinitive for 'to see'?
Conjugate 'sum' (to be) in first person singular present
Conjugate 'sum' (to be) in third person singular present
Conjugate 'sum' (to be) in third person plural present

vocabulary-family.title: Vocabulary: Family & People
vocabulary-family.description: Learn essential Latin vocabulary for family members and people

cards.question: What is the Latin word for 'father'?
What is the Latin word for 'mother'?
What is the Latin word for 'son'?
What is the Latin word for 'daughter'?

third-declension.title: Third Declension Nouns
third-declension.description: Master the complex third declension pattern

cards.question: What case shows possession in Latin?
cards.answer: Genitive case (Example: liber puerī = the book of the boy)

cards.question: What case is used for the direct object?
What case is used for the indirect object?
What case is used with certain prepositions and to show means/manner?
What is the nominative singular ending for third declension nouns?
What is the genitive singular ending for third declension nouns?
What is the accusative singular ending for third declension masculine/feminine nouns?
What is the nominative plural ending for third declension masculine/feminine nouns?
What is the genitive singular of 'rēx'?

vocabulary-nature-time.title: Vocabulary: Nature & Time
vocabulary-nature-time.description: Essential vocabulary for natural elements and time

cards.question: What is the marker for the perfect tense?
cards.answer: -v- or -u- in the stem (Example: amāvī = I loved/have loved)

cards.question: What are the perfect tense personal endings?
What is the first person singular perfect ending?
What is the second person singular perfect ending?
What is the third person singular perfect ending?
What is the third person plural perfect ending?
What are the two main ways to translate the perfect tense?
cards.answer: Simple past (loved) or present perfect (have loved)

cards.question: What are the four principal parts of a Latin verb?
cards.answer: 1st person present, present infinitive, 1st person perfect, perfect passive participle

subjunctive-mood.title: Subjunctive Mood
subjunctive-mood.description: Learn the subjunctive mood and its uses

cards.question: What is the present subjunctive first person singular ending?
How do you form the present subjunctive for first conjugation verbs?
How do you form the present subjunctive for second, third, and fourth conjugation verbs?
cards.answer: Add -a- before the personal endings (videam, dūcam, audiam...)

cards.question: What is a common use of the subjunctive in purpose clauses?
cards.answer: To express purpose with 'ut' (so that) or 'nē' (so that...not)

cards.question: Translate: Venit ut te videat
cards.answer: He comes so that he may see you (purpose)

cards.question: What conjunction introduces a result clause?
cards.answer: 'ut' (so that, with the result that) with subjunctive

cards.question: What is a jussive subjunctive?
cards.answer: Subjunctive used to express a command or exhortation (Let us...)

cards.question: What is a hortatory subjunctive?
cards.answer: First person plural subjunctive expressing encouragement (Let us...)

cards.question: Identify the mood and translate: amet
cards.answer: Present subjunctive - 'may he/she love' or 'let him/her love'

cards.question: How do you form the imperfect subjunctive?
cards.answer: Present infinitive + personal endings (amārem, amārēs, amāret...)

participles.title: Participles
participles.description: Master Latin participles and their uses

cards.question: What is the present active participle ending?
What is the perfect passive participle ending for first conjugation?
What is the perfect passive participle ending for second conjugation?
What is the perfect passive participle ending for third conjugation?
What is the perfect passive participle ending for fourth conjugation?
How do you form the future active participle?
cards.answer: Perfect passive stem + -ūrus, -a, -um (amātūrus = about to love)

cards.question: What are the three main uses of participles?
Translate: puella amāta
cards.answer: the girl having been loved / the loved girl

subordinate-clauses.title: Subordinate Clauses
subordinate-clauses.description: Learn various types of subordinate clauses

cards.question: What conjunction introduces a result clause?
cards.answer: 'ut' (so that, with the result that) with subjunctive

cards.question: How do you translate a result clause?
What conjunction introduces a concessive clause?
What conjunction introduces a causal clause?
What word introduces a conditional clause?
Identify the clause type: Tam fortis est ut vincit
cards.answer: Result clause - 'He is so brave that he wins'

deponent-verbs.title: Deponent Verbs
deponent-verbs.description: Learn verbs with passive forms but active meanings

cards.question: What are deponent verbs?
cards.answer: Verbs with passive forms but active meanings (Example: sequor = I follow)

cards.question: How can you recognize a deponent verb?
cards.answer: The first principal part ends in -or, but it has an active meaning

cards.question: What does 'sequitur' mean?
cards.answer: he/she/it follows (deponent verb, passive form, active meaning)

cards.question: What is the present active infinitive ending for first conjugation?
What is the present active infinitive ending for second conjugation?
What is the present active infinitive ending for third conjugation?
What is the present active infinitive ending for fourth conjugation?
What is the perfect active infinitive formation?
cards.answer: Perfect stem + -isse (Example: amāvisse = to have loved)

cards.question: How do you form the future active infinitive?
cards.answer: Future active participle + esse (Example: amātūrus esse = to be about to love)

cards.question: How do you form the perfect passive infinitive?
cards.answer: Perfect passive participle + esse (Example: amātus esse = to have been loved)

literary-terms.title: Literary Terms & Meter
literary-terms.description: Essential terms for understanding Latin poetry and prose

cards.question: What is 'dactyl' in Latin poetry?
cards.answer: A metrical foot consisting of one long syllable followed by two short syllables (— ∪ ∪)

cards.question: What is 'hexameter'?
cards.answer: A line of poetry with six metrical feet, commonly used in epic poetry

cards.question: What is 'caesura'?
cards.answer: A pause or break within a line of poetry

cards.question: What is 'enjambment'?
cards.answer: Continuation of a sentence beyond the end of a verse line

cards.question: What is 'anaphora'?
cards.answer: Repetition of words at the beginning of successive clauses

cards.question: What is 'chiasmus'?
cards.answer: Inverted parallelism in word order (ABBA pattern)

cards.question: What construction is used for indirect statement in Latin?
cards.answer: Accusative + Infinitive (Example: Dīcit eum venīre = He says that he is coming)

cards.question: What verb commonly introduces indirect statement?
cards.answer: Verbs of saying, thinking, knowing (dīcō, putō, sciō)

cards.question: Translate: Dīcit puellam venīre
cards.answer: He says that the girl is coming

cards.question: Translate: Scīmus tē esse bonum
cards.answer: We know that you are good

cards.question: What is a gerund in Latin?
cards.answer: A verbal noun formed from a verb (Example: amandī = of loving)

cards.question: What does a gerundive express?
cards.answer: Necessity or obligation (Example: amandus = needing to be loved)

cards.question: What is the typical Latin word order?
cards.answer: Subject - Object - Verb (SOV), though flexible for emphasis

cards.question: Where do adjectives typically appear in Latin?
cards.answer: After the noun they modify, though can precede for emphasis

cards.question: What work is Caesar famous for?
cards.answer: Commentāriī dē Bellō Gallicō (Commentaries on the Gallic War)

cards.question: What type of writing was Cicero known for?

conditional-clauses.title: Conditional Clauses
conditional-clauses.description: Master all types of conditional sentences

cards.question: What introduces a simple conditional in Latin?
What mood is used for contrary-to-fact conditions?
cards.answer: Subjunctive (imperfect for present, pluperfect for past)

cards.question: What is an ablative absolute?
cards.answer: A noun/pronoun + participle in ablative case, expressing circumstance (Example: urbe captā = the city having been captured)

cards.question: What is indirect question construction?
cards.answer: Interrogative word + subjunctive (Example: Rogat quid faciās = He asks what you are doing)

golden-age-authors.title: Golden Age Authors
golden-age-authors.description: Major prose authors of the Golden Age

cards.question: Who were the major prose authors of the Golden Age?
What characterizes Ciceronian prose style?
cards.answer: Long, elaborate periodic sentences with balanced clauses and rhythmic endings (clausulae)

cards.question: What characterizes Caesar's prose style?
cards.answer: Clear, direct, straightforward narrative with simple sentence structure

cards.question: What is a relative clause of purpose?
cards.answer: Relative pronoun (quī) + subjunctive to express purpose

cards.question: What is a relative clause of characteristic?
cards.answer: Quī + subjunctive to describe a type or class

cards.question: What conjunction means 'when' with perfect tense?
cards.answer: 'cum' with perfect indicative for definite past time

cards.question: What construction expresses fear in Latin?
Translate: senātus populusque Rōmānus (SPQR)
cards.answer: The Senate and People of Rome

cards.question: What is dactylic hexameter?
cards.answer: The meter of epic poetry: six feet of dactyls (— ∪ ∪) or spondees (— —)

cards.question: What is elegiac couplet?
cards.answer: Hexameter line followed by pentameter line, used in love poetry

catullus.title: Catullus
catullus.description: Learn about Catullus and his poetry

cards.question: What type of poetry did Catullus write?
cards.answer: Lyric poetry, love poetry (especially about Lesbia), and invective

cards.question: What are Virgil's three major works?
What is the opening line of the Aeneid?
cards.answer: Arma virumque canō (I sing of arms and the man)

cards.question: What is Ovid's most famous work?
What types of poetry did Horace write?
cards.answer: Odes (lyric poetry), Satires, Epistles, and Ars Poetica

cards.question: What is enjambment?
cards.answer: Continuation of a sentence beyond the end of a verse line

cards.question: What is caesura?
cards.answer: A pause or break within a line of poetry

cards.question: What is synchysis?
cards.answer: Interlocked word order (ABAB pattern) for artistic effect

cards.question: Who were the major Roman elegiac poets?
What is Livy's major historical work?
cards.answer: Ab Urbe Conditā (From the Founding of the City) - history of Rome

cards.question: What period does Livy's history cover?
cards.answer: From Rome's foundation (753 BCE) to his own time (Augustus)

cards.question: What are Tacitus's major historical works?
What characterizes Tacitus's writing style?
cards.answer: Dense, elliptical prose; cynical tone; psychological insight

cards.question: What historical works did Sallust write?
cards.answer: Bellum Catilīnae (Catiline Conspiracy) and Bellum Jugurthīnum (Jugurthine War)

cards.question: What is notable about Sallust's style?
What were the main Roman magistracies?
cards.answer: Consul, praetor, aedile, quaestor, tribune, censor

cards.question: What was the cursus honōrum?
cards.answer: The sequence of public offices held by aspiring Roman politicians

cards.question: What are the main periods of Roman history?
cards.answer: Monarchy (753-509 BCE), Republic (509-27 BCE), Empire (27 BCE-476 CE)

cards.question: Who was Rome's main enemy in the Punic Wars?
cards.answer: Carthage (especially Hannibal in the Second Punic War)

cards.question: When did Caesar cross the Rubicon?
What year marks the beginning of the Roman Empire?
What is a periphrastic conjugation?
cards.answer: Future active: future participle + esse; Passive of obligation: gerundive + esse

cards.question: What is a supine?
cards.answer: Verbal noun used with verbs of motion: accusative (-um) for purpose, ablative (-ū) with adjectives

cards.question: What is chiasmus?
cards.answer: Inverted parallelism (ABBA pattern): 'vīxēre fortēs ante Agamemnona multī' (Horace)

cards.question: What is anaphora?
cards.answer: Repetition of words at the beginning of successive clauses

cards.question: What is tricolon?
cards.answer: Series of three parallel elements, often with increasing length (Cicero's favorite)

cards.question: What is periodic structure?
cards.answer: Sentence where main idea is suspended until the end, characteristic of Cicero

cards.question: What are clausulae?
cards.answer: Rhythmic patterns at the end of prose sentences/clauses

cards.question: What is a mixed conditional?
cards.answer: Combining different time frames in protasis and apodosis

cards.question: What is the Greek accusative?
cards.answer: Accusative of respect/specification borrowed from Greek syntax

cards.question: What is brachylogy?
cards.answer: Condensed expression omitting easily understood elements

cards.question: What is genitive of characteristic?
cards.answer: Genitive with esse expressing characteristic quality (est stultī = it is characteristic of a fool)

cards.question: What is the historical infinitive?
cards.answer: Present infinitive used as main verb for vivid narrative

cards.question: What are Cicero's Catilinarian Orations?
cards.answer: Four speeches against Catiline's conspiracy (63 BCE)

cards.question: What is the famous opening of the First Catilinarian?
cards.answer: Quō usque tandem abūtēre, Catilīna, patientiā nostrā? (How long will you abuse our patience, Catiline?)

cards.question: What are Cicero's main philosophical works?
cards.answer: Dē Officiīs, Dē Amīcitiā, Dē Senectūte, Tusculan Disputations

cards.question: What are Cicero's works on rhetoric?

roman-rhetoric.title: Roman Rhetoric
roman-rhetoric.description: Learn the five parts and three types of rhetoric

cards.question: What are the five parts of rhetoric?
What are the three types of oratory?

oratorical-style.title: Oratorical Style
oratorical-style.description: Learn about rhetorical styles and appeals

cards.question: What are the three levels of style?
What are the three modes of persuasion?
What does 'Ō tempora! Ō mōrēs!' mean?
cards.answer: Oh the times! Oh the customs! (Cicero lamenting moral decline)

aeneid-structure.title: Aeneid Structure & Plot
aeneid-structure.description: Learn the structure and plot of the Aeneid

cards.question: How many books are in the Aeneid?
What is the basic plot of the Aeneid?
cards.answer: Aeneas's journey from Troy to Italy to found the Roman race

cards.question: Who is Dido?
cards.answer: Queen of Carthage who falls in love with Aeneas and commits suicide when he leaves

cards.question: Who is Turnus?
cards.answer: Italian warrior and rival of Aeneas for Lavinia's hand

cards.question: What is pietās in the Aeneid?
cards.answer: Duty, especially to gods, country, and family - Aeneas's defining virtue

cards.question: What does 'Arma virumque canō' mean?
cards.answer: I sing of arms and the man (opening line)

cards.question: What does 'Sunt lacrimae rērum' mean?
cards.answer: There are tears for things (the sadness of mortal life)

cards.question: What is an epic simile?
cards.answer: Extended comparison, often several lines long

cards.question: What is in mediās rēs?
cards.answer: Beginning in the middle of the action (epic convention)

cards.question: What is a catalog in epic?
cards.answer: Extended list (e.g., of ships, warriors, or places)

cards.question: What is Virgilian half-line?
cards.answer: Incomplete hexameter line, possibly left unfinished at Virgil's death

cards.question: What are the Eclogues?
cards.answer: Virgil's pastoral poems about shepherds and rural life

cards.question: What are the Georgics?
cards.answer: Virgil's didactic poem on farming and rural life in four books

cards.question: How does Medieval Latin differ from Classical Latin?
cards.answer: Simplified syntax, new vocabulary, Christian terminology, different pronunciation

cards.question: What is Vulgate Latin?
cards.answer: St. Jerome's Latin translation of the Bible (late 4th century)

cards.question: What characterized Renaissance Humanism?
cards.answer: Revival of classical Latin standards, imitation of Cicero, scholarship

scholarly-tools.title: Scholarly Tools
scholarly-tools.description: Essential reference works for Latin scholarship

cards.question: What is the Lewis and Short?
What is the OLD?
cards.answer: Oxford Latin Dictionary - modern scholarly Latin dictionary

cards.question: What is a critical apparatus?
cards.answer: Notes showing manuscript variants and editorial decisions

cards.question: What is paleography?
cards.answer: Study of ancient and medieval handwriting

cards.question: What is uncial script?
cards.answer: Type of capital letter script used in late antiquity

cards.question: What is the difference between literal and idiomatic translation?
cards.answer: Literal: word-for-word; Idiomatic: sense-for-sense preserving natural English
